A few more thoughts to consider. If your sword is a shinto sw=
ord, it 
was almost for certain carried by a samurai. The question then 
be=
comes, if this sword was good enough for a real samurai without a 
bo-hi, h=
ow is it that it is suddenly not good enough without a bo-hi 
now? 

Additi=
onally, isn't cutting a 'striking event', and if it is, isn't 
final moment=
um a critical factor in addition to cutting motion? And, 
isn't momentum ma=
de up of mass X velocity? Therefore, by removing 
metal for a bo-hi won't t=
hat reduce the mass, thereby reduce the 
striking force of the cut? While y=
ou could possibly increase the 
velocity with a lighter sword to compensate=
 some, the best result 
would come from a combination of both.

Historicall=
y, the reason for bo-hi is to reduce battle fatigue 
(lactic acid build up)=
 from making cut after cut for an extended 
period of time.
